headline: The Largest Bitcoin ETF Is Posting Record Outflows
summary: Investors are yanking cash from BlackRock's smash-hit bitcoin ETF at the fastest pace on record amid a selloff in the cryptocurrency. The iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF has posted a net $2.2 billion outflow in November through Friday, according to FactSet, by far its largest ever.

headline: BlackRock and AccessFintech Announce Strategic Partnership to Enhance Post-Trade Connectivity and Workflows
summary: BlackRock, Inc. (NYSE: BLK) and AccessFintech (AFT), a leading data and workflow collaboration network for financial markets, today announced a strategic partnership. headline: Bitcoin Funds Head for Worst Month as $3.5 Billion Pulled
summary: Investors have pulled $3.5 billion from the US-listed Bitcoin ETFs so far in November, almost equaling the previous monthly record for outflows of $3.6 billion set in February, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.  BlackRock Inc.’s Bitcoin fund IBIT, which accounts for about 60% of the cohort’s assets, has registered $2.2 billion in redemptions in November, meaning it will slump to its worst month barring a sharp reversal.  The outflows come with Bitcoin itself set for its worst monthly performance since the crypto industry collapse of 2022, a daisy chain of corporate failures punctuated by the downfall of Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX.

The outflows come with Bitcoin itself set for its worst monthly performance since the crypto industry collapse of 2022, a daisy chain of corporate failures punctuated by the downfall of Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX.

headline: BlackRock Says Equities Repatriation Theme Has 'Legs to Grow'
summary: Ursula Marchioni, investment and portfolio solutions EMEA head at BlackRock, says investors are looking to diversify their equity holdings away from concentrated trades. The repatriation theme which has characterized European and Asian investment portfolios "has still has legs to grow," Marchioni tells Bloomberg Television.

headline: Why Wall Street Wants to Sell Private Markets Data
summary: $1.8 billion That's how much S&P Global plans to spend to buy With Intelligence, becoming the latest Wall Street bastion to splurge for a private-asset data provider. BlackRock paid $3.2 billion for Preqin in March.
